body.title: Creating a new content set
body.p: The SPFE Open Toolkit (SPFE-OT) builds a collection of web pages or other output format from a collection of topics that you specify in a content set.

section.title: Why do I need a content set?
section.p: A content set is the master plan that the SPFE Open Toolkit will use to generate output content. You must have a content-set configuration file to to run the SPFE build system to create output.

section.title: What is a content set?
section.p: A content set is the collection of topics that you specify in a content-set configuration file. The SPFE-OT build system uses the the content-set configuration file to collect the source content and process it as a whole to generate HTML or other output format. The configuration file doesn't list the topics directly but specifies one or more topic-sets. Each topic set has its own configuration file that does specify the topics it includes.
Thus, to generate output using the SPFE-OT, you'll need a content-set configuration file that specifies one or more topic sets.

section.title: What decisions do I need to make when planning a content set?
section.p: Before diving in, take a moment to consider how you organize topics and file locations will affect how you work and what you create.

li.p: Topics: Though each topic should be a complete, functional unit, topics do have affinites by addressing similar subjects. Users will appreciate when closely related topics are easy to find. One way to associate topics is to place them in the same topic set.
File locations: While you can include topic files in a topic set wherever they may be in the file system, you'll find it much simpler to organize files that belong to a topic set in a single folder.

section.title: How do I create a content-set configuration file?
section.p: Create an XML file in the content set configuration structure and locate it in the same directory you will execute builds.
